abstract.p: *Maggie Cassidy letter, commenting on July 2 article) says New York City should address its teacher shortage by providing internships for prospective teachers, training for mentors and incentives to bring the most skilled, experienced and committed teachers to its neediest schools

block.p: New York City's plan to hire 250 professionals and place them as teachers in the city's most troubled schools after one month of training (news article, July 2) is unfair to both those well-intentioned adults and to the children in those schools.

Before taking responsibility for a full teaching load, a beginning teacher needs an extended internship in a classroom, supervised by a trained, empathic mentor. This plan does not provide that experience.

New York City's plan to hire 250 professionals and place them as teachers in the city's most troubled schools after one month of training (news article, July 2) is unfair to both those well-intentioned adults and to the children in those schools.

Before taking responsibility for a full teaching load, a beginning teacher needs an extended internship in a classroom, supervised by a trained, empathic mentor. This plan does not provide that experience.

New York needs to address the teaching shortage by providing internships for prospective teachers, training for mentors and incentives to bring the most skilled, experienced and committed teachers to its neediest schools.
The writer is associate director of the Teacher Knowledge Project at the School for International Training.
